awd_titl_txt: AitF:Collaborative Research: Bridging the Gap between Theory and Practice for Matching and Edge Cover Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Every year the 19,000 students who graduate from medical schools in the U.S. are  matched with the hospitals where they will do their residency training. Both students and hospitals rank their choices, and an algorithm is used to find a matching that gives each student their best available choice. These problems also arise in other contexts: matching organ donors to recipients whose bodies will not reject the transplanted organ, matching advertisements to web surfers based on their interests, etc. Variations of matching problems, and related edge cover problems, are formalized in computer science on combinatorial objects called graphs, and involve beautiful mathematics, sophisticated algorithms, efficient implementations of these algorithms on modern desk-top computers and supercomputers, and empirical evaluation on a number of problems that arise in application areas such as computational science and engineering, data science, network science, etc.  In this project, the two PIs will develop new algorithms and software for matching and edge cover problems, and make implementations available for practitioners in various fields of science, engineering and industry. The PIs will also train two PhD students in this project, and develop teaching resources to make these developments accessible to undergraduate and graduate students in computer science. 

The problem of computing a matching that maximizes some objective function has been actively investigated for decades, driven by many high-profile industrial and medical applications.  This project focuses on the design, theoretical analysis, and implementation of matching algorithms that meet the needs of modern applications, and considers generalized matching problems such as b-matching, b-edge cover, and metric matching.  Classical serial algorithms that compute exactly optimum matchings are not always suited to massive graph data sets, which can contain billions of edges.  Fortunately, in many applications it suffices to have nearly optimum matchings rather than exactly optimum ones.  One goal of this project is to design simple and efficient matching algorithms that are both highly parallel, and produce provably good approximate solutions.

This project will examine several open problems on the approximability of generalized weighted matching problems, particularly on which matching-type problems admit linear time algorithms with approximation factor arbitrarily close to one.  To that end, the PIs will study how relaxing standard linear programming formulations of generalized weighted matching problems allows for more efficient algorithms. These and other algorithms will be modified to make them efficient on modern processors that support parallel computing. 

Two PhD students will be trained in this project. Generalized graph matching algorithms are now applied in numerical linear algebra software, for preconditioning, graph clustering, anonymizing data, and network alignment.  The PIs will evaluate the performance of new and existing algorithms on these applications.  The PIs will make freely available all code of matching algorithms developed under this project.

Basic matching algorithms from the mid-20th century are firmly established in the canon of computer science education, but few modern matching algorithms are taught at the undergraduate level.  The PIs will incorporate modules on modern matching and applications into their courses at Purdue University and the University of Michigan, and make these materials publicly available.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerned the design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms for computing  significant subgraphs of a combinatorial graph. We have taken the approach of computing degree-constrained significant subgraphs, since they are vital to many applications.  Two examples are  matching and edge cover problems in graphs, with  their several variants. We designed  both approximate and exact algorithms, and applied them to fields such as combinatorial scientific computing, data privacy, machine learning, and quantum chemistry. Our focus was on the role that fast approximation algorithms can play for these challenging combinatorial problems when massive graphs, with billions of edges or more,  are involved.

 The  project addressed the large gap between theory and practice for degree-constrained subgraph computations. For matching problems, we designed new approximation algorithms for four variants of the matching problem. For edge cover problems, we employed several paradigms to design new approximation algorithms. Parallel approximation algorithms were designed by taking advantage of the fact that some algorithms needed only local information in the graph to make decisions.  Some of the new algorithms were applied to solve problems in data privacy, load balancing parallel computations in quantum chemistry, efficient solvers for sparse linear systems of equations, and graph construction in machine learning and data analytics contexts.

The project  involved  collaboration between a PI in applied and computational discrete algorithms (ACDA) and a theoretical computer scientist. Their research groups met and discussed several of these problems during the duration of the project, which led to the study of problems of interest to each of the PIs, and to efficient implementations of some algorithms designed by the theoretical computer scientist.

Three  students wrote their PhD theses  on  the collection of matching and edge cover problems considered here. One of them is now employed as a research scientist at a U.S. Department of Energy Lab, Pacific Northwest National Lab, and a second student will work as a post-doctoral scientist at Purdue University. A third student is an Assistant Professor of computer science at the King Fahd University in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia.

We have published thirteen papers on b-matchings, b-edge covers, submodular matchings, bi-objective matchings, and their applications in highly ranked journals and conferences, during this project period. One of these papers is a 93-page  article on Approximation Algorithms in Combinatorial Scientific Computing, that surveys our work on this topic,  in the journal Acta Numerica published by  the Cambridge University Press.  This  journal  publishes about eight papers each year, each article is by invitation  of the editorial board only,  and it has the highest impact factor (9.7 in 2019)  among all journals in applied and computational mathematics. A second paper on a new algorithm for submodular b-matching  and its application to quantum chemistry was published in the Proceedings of the first SIAM Conference on Applied and Computational Discrete Algorithms (ACDA) in 2021. Our work was presented at invited and keynote talks at international conferences (SIAM CSC, SIAM Annual Meeting, etc.), and at universities such as MIT and Waterloo (the Tutte Colloquium).

A software library for matching problems caled MatchBox was created from the algorithms designed and implemented in this project, and it was shared with industry, National Labs in the U.S., and international groups of researchers. It is available on Github for download with suitable license for free use.

The PI helped to create the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics  Activity Group on Applied and Computational Discrete Algorithms (SIAM-ACDA), and served as its founding chair during 2019-2020. The first SIAM Conference on ACDA with published Proceedings was organized in July 2021. The ACDA community brings together a number of researchers from communities such as combinatorial scientific computing, theoretical computer science, operations research, combinatorial mathematics, algorithmic differentiation, parallel computing, etc., who are interested in the application of algorithms to solve problems in science, engineering, and information science.
